title: 113_s410
content: The Act is titled the "Wall Street Trading and Speculators Tax Act" and introduces a tax on trading transactions in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Wall Street Trading and Speculators Tax Act" imposes a 0.03 percent tax on covered transactions involving securities. The specified base amount for the tax is the fair market value of the security or the amount of any payment. Covered transactions include purchases on U.S. facilities or involving U.S. persons. The "Wall Street Trading and Speculators Tax Act" imposes a 0.03 percent tax on covered transactions involving securities traded on U.S. facilities or involving U.S. persons. The term 'security' includes various financial instruments such as stocks, bonds, derivatives, currencies, and notional principal contracts. The term 'notional principal contract' refers to a financial instrument involving payments at specified intervals based on a specified index. The term 'notional principal contract' involves payments based on an index, with exceptions for initial security issuances under certain conditions. The tax imposed by this section shall be paid by facilities in the United States for transactions or purchases executed by a U.S. broker. The tax imposed by this section applies to transactions involving U.S. persons, with specific rules for direct transactions. Payments for certain securities are treated as separate transactions. Payments for certain securities, including notional principal contracts, forward contracts, and options, are treated as separate transactions for tax purposes. Controlled foreign corporations are treated as United States persons under this section. Special rules apply for tax payments on direct transactions by United States shareholders. The tax payable by a controlled foreign corporation under subsection (g)(2) is instead paid by United States shareholders based on their proportion of stock ownership. Definitions for 'United States shareholder' and 'controlled foreign corporation' are provided in sections 951(b) and 957(a) respectively. The Secretary will administer this section in consultation with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. The Secretary will provide guidance and regulations to prevent avoidance of the purposes of this section, including the use of non-United States persons in transactions. Additionally, a new section is added to provide a credit with respect to certain tax-favored accounts to offset transaction tax. The new section provides a credit to offset transaction tax for certain tax-favored accounts. A credit is allowed against the tax for the taxable year equal to 0.03 percent of the taxpayer's qualified tax-favored account contributions. Qualified contributions include amounts to retirement plans, Archer MSAs, health savings accounts, and qualified tuition programs. The text chunk discusses amendments related to qualified tuition programs and Coverdell education savings accounts for designated beneficiaries. It includes changes to section 1324(b)(2) of title 31 and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The text chunk introduces amendments related to a tax on trading transactions, effective after December 31, 2013. It includes changes to section 6038(a)(1) regarding information reporting for controlled foreign corporations. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of subchapters for chapter 36 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
